channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pakistani Justices Suspend Executions Ordered by Military Courts
item.description: A petition by a rights activist and lawyer challenged trials by the military courts and questioned whether prisoners were tried fairly.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Paranoia and Polarization in Turkey
item.description: Erdogan is alienating allies, curtailing civil liberties and stoking sectarianism simply for the sake of political gain.
item.dc:creator: MUSTAFA AKYOL

item.title: Doubling of Search Zone Planned if Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 Isn’t Found Before June
item.description: Officials from Malaysia, Australia and China are prepared to expand their search for the Malaysia Airlines jet that’s been missing for more than a year.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER and MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: A crew member from the Royal Malaysian Air Force during a search operation for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 in the Strait of Malacca last year.

item.title: Images Show China Building Aircraft Runway in Disputed Spratly Islands
item.description: Satellite images released Thursday show a strip expected to be able to handle fighter jets and surveillance aircraft under construction in the South China Sea.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: CNES, Distribution Airbus DS, via IHS
item.media:description: Satellite imagery provided by Airbus shows a before-and-after view of Fiery Cross Reef.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Macedonia Steps Backward
item.description: Our promising future as an E.U. member is being undermined by government eavesdropping and corruption.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: NIKOLA DIMITROV

item.title: Snub at Ferry Memorial Shows Rawness of Wounds in South Korea
item.description: At an anniversary service, President Park Geun-hye called on the country to move past the sinking that killed more than 300, but victims’ relatives refused to see her.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea, center, paid tribute to the ferry victims on Thursday on the island of Jindo, but relatives of the dead would not meet with her.

item.title: Turkey’s Century of Denial About an Armenian Genocide
item.description: Nearly 1.5 million Armenians died at the hands of the Ottoman Empire in 1915, during World War I. Turks by and large do not believe mass killings were planned.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Preserving the Ghastly Inventory of Auschwitz
item.description: The aim of the foundation maintaining the site of the concentration camp is “to preserve authenticity.” It is a moral stance with specific curatorial challenges.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A display of childrens’ shoes belonging to some of the victims of the camps.

item.title: Tensions Flare Between Iraq and Saudi Arabia in U.S. Coalition
item.description: An exchange between Iraq and Saudi Arabia reflected the challenges facing the Obama administration as it tries to hold together a diverse coalition in the fight against the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi of Iraq, center, on Capitol Hill on Wednesday. He is making his first official visit to Washington.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Pushing Back Against the Authorities in China ‘According to the Law’
item.description: Supporters are demanding the Chinese government compensate and apologize to feminists for detaining them, and one group says it will engage a lawyer to defend its reputation against official criticism of involvement in the high-profile case.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The released feminists, from left: Li Tinging, Wei Tingting, Wang Man, Zheng Churan and Wu Rongrong, whose supporters are now lobbying for them to receive compensation and a public apology.

item.title: World Briefing: Japan: Tensions in the Region Keep Defense Forces’ Jets Busy
item.description: The number of planes scrambled by the country’s defense forces had surged in recent years, nearly matching such activity during the Cold War amid growing activity by China and Russia in the region.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Egypt: Blast Kills Military Cadets
item.description: Students waiting for a bus at a military academy were killed by a roadside bomb on Wednesday in what appeared to be the latest in a series of attacks by militant groups.
item.dc:creator: MERNA THOMAS

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Party Official Is Arrested
item.description: The federal police on Wednesday detained the treasurer of the governing Workers’ Party, João Vaccari Neto, in connection with an investigation into corruption at the state-run oil giant Petrobras.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: France: Radio Strike Is Ending
item.description: Four weeks after protesting a proposed reorganization that would have resulted in hundreds of layoffs, striking employees of Radio France returned to work Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: Siberian Fires Spread
item.description: Dozens have died in raging brush fires that emergency workers have been unable to quell for nearly a week.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW ROTH

item.title: World Briefing: Mali: Suicide Bomber Attacks U.N. Base
item.description: At least three people were killed when a bomber attacked a United Nations peacekeeping base in northern Mali on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Survey Offers Rare Window Into Chinese Political Culture
item.description: A draft research paper finds that China may be divided, much like the United States, into “red” conservative provinces mostly in the poorer rural interior and richer and urbanized “blue” coastal provinces.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: An intersection in Beijing, on Nov. 26, 2014. A new study provides insights into what Chinese are thinking on a range of social and political issues.

item.title: Iran Is Raising Sophistication and Frequency of Cyberattacks, Study Says
item.description: A new study concludes that Iran has greatly increased the frequency and skill of its cyberattacks, even while negotiating with world powers over its nuclear program.
item.category: American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: Barriers Remain for American Business in Cuba
item.description: President Obama’s removal of Cuba from the list of state sponsors of terrorism goes only a short way to reconnecting American businesses with Cuba, experts said.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:description: A youth fair in Santiago, Cuba. "American companies need to be sober" about their prospects for doing business on the island, an expert said.

item.title: Ansan Journal: A Year After Sewol Ferry Tragedy, Peace Is Elusive for South Korean City
item.description: Ansan still seems bewildered as residents prepare to mark the anniversary of the sinking that killed 250 of its high school students and 11 teachers.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Photos, flowers, letters and gifts are left on victims' desks in a classroom at Danwon High School.
